section.title: used to/would
section.sectiontitle: Use used to to talk about past habits and states which are no longer true.
section.text1a: I used to live in Rome.
section.text2a: She didn't use to like olives.
section.sectiontitle2: There is no 'd' in the spelling of use to in negatives and questions.
section.text3a: We didn't use to like our teacher.
section.text4a: Did you use to study art?

section.title: used to/would
section.sectiontitle: Use would to talk about past habits only.
section.text1: They used to meet every day.
section.text2a:
I used to love that programme.
(NOT I would love that programme.)
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Past Simple, not used to, to describe how long something lasted.
section.text3a:
I worked in Italy for five years.
(NOT I used to work in Italy for five years.)
section.text4a: She studied English in London for six months. (NOT She used to study in London for six months.)

section.title: used to/would
section.sectiontitle: Use the Past Simple, not used to/would, to talk about a single event in the past.
section.text1a:
I broke my leg skiing.
(NOT I used to break my leg skiing.)
section.text2a:
They got married in 1996.
(NOT They used to get married in 1996.)
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Present Simple, not used to, to talk about habits which are true now.
section.text3a: I usually play football three times a week.
section.text4a: We go to the beach every weekend.
